Today was a truly special day in Moyale as we embarked on an entourage through Moyale town, marking Day 63 of the Horn of Africa Elephant Campaign Walk.

 I am thrilled to announce that the Elephant Campaign team has reached the Ethiopia border in Moyale, a significant milestone in our journey.

 I want to extend my heartfelt thanks to the entire team that accompanied me today: ACC Moyale, Mr. Martin Muhia; the KWS team led by Warden Mr. Abdi Kampicha; OCPD Mr. George Kipkoros; AP Commander (PPU) Mr. Shadrack Yego; Deputy Officer in Charge of Moyale Prison, Mr. Kodeck Mose; Deputy OCS, Mr. Samora Bala; Subcounty AP Commander, Mr. Geoffrey Elongi; the KDF team led by Lieutenant Mr. M. Kassim; Border Liaison Officer, Major Ruto; the Peace Forum team led by Chair Mr. Mohamed; and the Dabel Conservancy team led by Mr. Ali Bule.

Walking through Moyale town and engaging with the residents was a powerful experience. It was an opportunity to share the message of conservation with the local community and to emphasize the importance of protecting our wildlife and environment. 

The presence of local leaders and security personnel made the day even more impactful, as it demonstrated a unified effort between different sectors of society—government, security forces, and conservationists—working together toward a common goal.

After the walk, I, along with KWS Warden Mr. Abdi Kampicha, had the pleasure of inviting the entire team to the KWS camp for lunch. 

Sharing a meal together was more than just an act of hospitality; it was a moment to reflect on and celebrate the progress we have made so far in the Elephant Campaign Walk. It allowed us to  strengthen our bonds, and appreciate the collective effort that has brought us this far.

Eating together symbolizes unity and the importance of working as a team to achieve common goals. It was a time to not only celebrate our accomplishments but also to recharge and prepare for the journey ahead, knowing that every step we take is a step toward securing a future where both people and wildlife can thrive. @KWSKenya

Ethiopia's 'Abuna Yemata Guh' is arguably the most inaccessible place of worship on earth and has to be climbed on foot to reach. Located in the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, this ancient rock-hewn church stands atop a vertical cliff, perched at an elevation of around 2,580 meters (8,460 feet). It is considered one of the most inaccessible and challenging religious sites to reach in the world.

The construction of rock-hewn churches in Ethiopia has a long history dating back to the 4th century AD, during the time of the Aksumite Empire. These churches were built by carving into solid rock formations, creating impressive architectural masterpieces. The rock-hewn churches served as centers of religious devotion and provided shelter during times of conflict.

Abuna Yemata Guh is believed to have been carved out of the cliff face during the 5th century, making it over 1,500 years old. It is dedicated to Saint Yemata, a legendary Ethiopian saint who is said to have meditated and prayed in this secluded location. The church is named after Abuna (meaning "father" in Amharic) Yemata, who was a prominent Ethiopian religious leader.

What makes Abuna Yemata Guh particularly notable is the challenging ascent required to reach it. Pilgrims and visitors must hike up a steep and narrow footpath, navigating rugged terrain and exposed ledges. The ascent involves scrambling up the cliff face, sometimes using ropes for support. This arduous journey symbolizes a spiritual pilgrimage, testing the devotion and commitment of those seeking solace and connection with their faith.

Despite its remote and inaccessible location, Abuna Yemata Guh has attracted attention in recent years as a testament to Ethiopia's rich cultural heritage and architectural prowess. It is not only a place of worship but also a symbol of the enduring faith and determination of the Ethiopian people.

Furthermore, the Tigray region, where Abuna Yemata Guh is situated, has witnessed significant historical and cultural events throughout the centuries. It has been a center of religious and political power, with various empires and kingdoms rising and falling in the region. Today, Tigray is home to a diverse population, including the Tigrayan people, who have their unique language, culture, and traditions.

In recent years, the Tigray region has faced challenging times due to internal conflicts and humanitarian crises, making access to sites like Abuna Yemata Guh more difficult. Nevertheless, the church continues to be a testament to Ethiopia's rich history and the resilience of its people, reminding us of the enduring power of faith and the importance of preserving cultural heritage.

The incredible site of the mountain church, Abuna Yemata Guh, is a monolithic church located in the Hawzen woreda of the Tigray Region, Ethiopia. It is situated at a height of 2,580 meters (8,460 ft).

According to local tradition, the church was built in the sixth century by one of the Nine Saints, Abuna Yemata. The Nine Saints are said to have come to Ethiopia from various regions, including Rome, Constantinople, and Syria, to spread Christianity and establish a monastic tradition. The paintings in the church are original and have been well-preserved due to the dry air and lack of humidity.

To access the church, one must climb a steep cliff with hand and feet holes carved into it. The ascent is considered hazardous and requires both physical strength and mental fortitude. Abuna Yemata Guh is one of 35 churches in Ethiopia that is built into a high place, making it a unique and awe-inspiring site to visit.

Meskel Celebration thrives in Adigrat, Eastern #Tigray
---
Adigrat, a town in Eastern Tigray, buzzes with vibrant celebration for a holiday locally known as Meskel, the Finding of the True Cross which is celebrated on September 27. Meskel festivities commenced in Adigrat on the eve of the holiday, drawing thousands of residents and visitors to public squares and churches in which bonfires were built topped by a Cross to which flowers and bundles of tied-up twigs and sticks, known as Shig are tied.  

Today, the celebration began early in the morning with a procession led by clergymen and priests organizing special services, featuring hymns and prayers dedicated to the significance of the Cross in Orthodox Christian faith. The celebration took place in the presence of Getachew Reda, President of the Interim Administration in Tigrai along with his Deputy, Lt General Tsadkan Gebretinsae, Arch Bishop of the Eastern Tigray Diocese, and Head of Tigrai Culture and Tourism Bureau, Atsbeha Gebregzabher. 

Speaking at the celebration, Getachew emphasized on the need to fully address all the challanges of the people of Tigray, urging politicians to move beyond personal and group interests and start advocating for substantial political change that empowers the younger generation to engage in meaningful and constructive activities. 

During his address at the celebration, Archbishop Abune Ephrem stressed on the importance of unity and reconcilation in preserving the rich cultural and religious practices of Mesqel before orchestrating the lightning ceremony.

Hargeisa, Somaliland – President of the Republic of Somaliland, H.E. Muse Bihi Abdi, announced that Somaliland and #Ethiopia are determined to move forward with the implementation of their recently agreed-upon bilateral accord. While he confirmed that the agreement will be put into effect, he refrained from specifying a timeline for its execution.

In an interview with Al Arabiya TV, a Gulf-based news network, and monitored by the Somaliland News Agency (SOLNA), President Bihi expressed confidence that Somaliland will gain international recognition, whether in the near or distant future.

Discussing the agreement with Ethiopia, President Bihi emphasized that it promises significant economic benefits for the Horn of Africa. As part of the accord, Ethiopia has agreed to recognize Somaliland’s independence and, in return, will lease a naval base from Somaliland. He described the agreement as a partnership based on mutual interests.

The president also highlighted strong domestic support for the agreement, stating that both the people of Somaliland and its political leadership see the deal with Ethiopia as crucial for Somaliland’s future.

Reflecting on the historical context, President Bihi noted that Somaliland and Somalia were once two independent nations that united in 1960. However, that union collapsed after 31 years, following a period of conflict and genocide against the people of Somaliland. He recalled that in 1991, Somaliland's elders convened a national conference to reclaim the country’s independence, reaffirming Somaliland’s statehood based on the will of its people, who remain committed to their sovereignty.

The president further remarked on Somalia’s continued recognition by Arab League nations, which he criticized for ignoring Somaliland. He expressed frustration with these countries for publicly stating that "Somaliland is not recognized" while failing to engage with the region.

President Bihi also emphasized Somaliland’s long-standing efforts to secure its independence over the past 34 years. He contrasted Somaliland’s stability with the ongoing turmoil and security issues in Somalia, where militant groups like Al-Shabaab and ISIS continue to operate. He affirmed that Somaliland’s coastline remains free of piracy and terrorism and open for global trade. 

The president vowed that Somaliland would defend itself should Somalia attempt any form of aggression.

In response to a question regarding Somaliland’s recent closure of Egypt’s cultural center, President Bihi explained that Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi had spoken of restoring the “unity of Somalia.” Bihi dismissed this claim, suggesting that President el-Sisi should be asked to clarify what he meant by a “unified Somalia.”
